Help

The Carnatic Music Transliterator allows you to create text for carnatic music compositions in a "unified" transliteration scheme so that it can be effectively rendered in all the carnatic music languages (sanskrit, telugu, tamizh, kannada and malayalam). See Unified Transliteration Scheme for Carnatic Music Compositions for more information on the scheme.

General Usage

You can either start typing from scratch, or you can paste HTML or word content. Use the various formatting buttons on top to create text in bold, italic, underline, and also to create bullet list, numbered lists, headings etc. As mentioned above, the text is expected to be in the unified transliteration scheme for carnatic music

Once you have created the text, you use the button to translate to the various languages. Use the tabs on top to switch between different languages

Paragraphs (RETURN) and newlines (Shift+RETURN)

When entering text, if you press the RETURN key, the editor will create a new paragraph. If you instead want to new just a new line without the additional space taken by paragraph, press Shift key while pressing the RETURN key.

Printable View, Printinng

Once you have translated the transliteration text to the target languages, you can switch to a printable view using the Printable View link the bottom. This view includes only the contents for the selected language(s), which you can then print to your printer using the print options of the browser.

Getting back to the editor - the Back link

The printable view, includes a Back link to take you back to the editor. You should use this link and not the Back button of your browser. Note that as desired, the Back link will not be included in your hard copy print.

Including more than one language in printable view

By default, the printable view will include the translation for the currently selected target language. So, if you are currently viewing Telugu, and you click on the Printable View link, the printable view will include only the Telugu rendition. You can include multiple languages, and also control the order in which the languages appear by changing the print options.

To view the print options, click on the + button next to the Printable View link. This will show two lists side by side with two buttons >> and << in-between. The left side list contains all the languages including a special entry <Current> to indicate the currently selected language. The right side list contains the languages that will be included in the printable view in the order they appear in the list. Use the >> button to add a language to the printable view. Use the << button to remove a language from the printable view.

Variables - what are they and how to use them

Some common terms which appear in carnatic music books outside of the actual lyrics (i.e. sAhitya) have various spelling and pronounciations in the different languages. For example, "Raga" (as in raga of the krithi), is rAga in kannada but rAgam in tamizh. So if you enter it as rAga in the input, then the translation would be inappropriate for tamizh as it would appear as ராக in tamizh. On the other hand, if you specify it as rAgam, then it would appear as ರಾಗಂ, which is less than ideal than ರಾಗ. There are many many examples of such terms in this category:
  • The term for language as in of a krithi (bAsha in sanskrit, kannada, but bashai or the better mozhi in tamizh),
  • Names of composers such as tyAgarAja (which would be spelt as tiyAgarAjar in tamizh) Some raga names like AbhOgi (abhOgi in kannada, telugu), kAmbhOji (kAmbOdi in tamizh)

Currently, the list of variables are pre-defined, and only a handful are supported at this point

To solve this problem, the editor has the concept of a variable, which is a term in the input that translates to different words according to the language. There are several ways of introducing variables into the content that needs to be transliterated.

How to insert a variable

To insert a variable at the current location, you click on the button. This will bring up a window from which you can select the variable you want to insert. The inserted variable will be shown in blue text with a gray background (e.g. rAga).

How to convert normal text to a variable

If you have already entered in a text, you can tell the editor to convert it into a variable by clicking on button. The editor will grab the current word, and search the list of pre-defined variables for a match. It will compare the current word against the english transliteration for all of the languages for a match. If a match is found, it will transform the current word into a variable (which will turn it into bluex text against a gray background).

Note that the text in the english translation, would be the text you entered. This points at an advantage of using the button vs. the button in that you have more control over how the text appears in the english "translation". For example, for the the variable for raga, if you use the button, the english text will always be rAga. However, with this approach, your input text could be any one of rAga, raga, Raga, rAgam, rAgamu etc., and all these will convert to the same variable, and the english "translation" will retain the original text.

Find and replace suitable words to variables

: If you are pasting text from an existing source, then it may be convenient to click on the button. This will search the text for words that are suitable for translation to variables. This can save the trouble of figuring out which words in your text should be variables. Words that are suitable are ones that appear in bold amongst themselves, as in the context of headings, and also words in a certain form (e.g. Raga: i.e. a word that matches a variable value and is followed by a colon).

Of course, using the may not always work flawlessly, in which case you can use the other approaches to insert new variables, and convert individual words to variables.

Miscellanous

Remove hyperlinks

If you are pasting text from an existing HTML source (as in a web-page), you may want to remove the anchors which are usually shown underlined in a browser, which you may not want in your transliterated content. You can do this by clicking on the button.

Clear Contents

Use button to clear the contents of the editor.
